author: Erylion
title: A beautiful thing.
review:
Parts

Includes two 2x4 bricks, one of which has the USB drive embedded within.  The brick with the USB drive also has a small loop and cord meant for a keychain.  The cord is very thin but very sturdy.  I give the 'model' a 5 for parts simply because it's a USB drive built into a brick!

The completed model

The drive allots you 8 gigs of storage.  The USB 2.0's male connector is standard-A, and has no metal sheath.  It is retractable, hiding perfectly inside the brick.  On the underside of the brick there is a switch, which allows you to push the connector out or pull it back in.  This is a bit of a two-edged sword though, because the connector often gets pushed back into the brick when you are attempting to plug it into a device, and there is no locking mechanism to keep it in the 'out' position.  The simple solution to this is to hold the switch forward as you insert the connector into a device.

Despite this design flaw, it really is a beautiful combination of computing technology and LEGO.  I currently use the brick to store music.  My car's sound system has a USB port, so I load up the brick with a wide array of tunes and plug it in.  I'm not a Mac fan, so this setup is a great alternative to itunes.  But I digress.

While 8 gigs of storage space is hardly earth-shattering these days, it's still a respectable amount considering you're not going to run substantial applications from an external USB 2.0 drive.  The space should be sufficient to hold numerous documents, image files, songs, old-school video game emulators, you name it.  In this regard, it's 'playability' is endless.

Being that the drive is encased in a 2x4 brick, the potential for customizability is also endless.  I imagine this would also appeal to Raspberry Pi builders, as I have seen a number of LEGO-built cases for such.  Having an external LEGO USB drive would make it easy to keep with the motif. 

Overall opinion

There are certainly less expensive USB drives on the market, but the sheer charm of having one that fits into a LEGO brick is hard to ignore.  Although I received mine as a gift, I would absolutely be willing to pay for one.
